div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,509] ALEXANDRIA, SATURDAY, JUNE 2, 1906. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.
Subject to the usual 25% reduction for returning.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

div.head: THE BAGHDAD RAILWAY.
div.p: The revival of interest in the Baghdad Rail way scheme with the rumours of an Anglo- Russian understanding have evoked consider able discussion in the home Press. The, "Morning Post's" correspondent at Berlin? writes that ho is assured from an official sourde that there is no truth in the rumours which are circulating in generally well-informed circles that negotiations are afoot with the object of effecting a reversal of the decision formed by Mr Balfour's Cabinet three years ago to refrain from encouraging the participa- tion of British capital in the Baghdad Railway. Germany, he is informed, has certainly made no fresh overtures and Sir Edward Grey, to judge by his recant statement in the House of Commons, does not contemplate taking any initiative in this question.

The circumstance has not been forgotten in Berlin that, according to reports authenti- cated at the time, both Mr. Balfour and the Marquis of Lansdowne were personally in favour of the association of British capital in the German enterprise. Those statesmen were, however, out-voted by their colleagues, who are supposed to have been influenced by the anti- German articles of two prominent London journals. This being so, it has always been felt in authoritative circles in Germany that the future might bring about a revocation or a modification of the negative attitude adopted by the Balfour Cabinet. That time, however, in the opinion of the German Government, has not yet arrived.

Meanwhile the belief is widespread in Berlin that German diplomacy is planning to improve its position as regards the prospects of the Baghdad Railway and also of trade generally in Central and Western Asia by taking a hand in the struggle for influence in Persia. The policy of Germany hitherto has been practically one of abstention from all diplomatic activity in the Dominions of the Shah, bat there are now several indications, including the recent appoint- ment of her new and remarkably able Minister to Teheran and the establishment of a steamship service to the Persian Gulf, that she is preparing to abandon this attitude and to make her influence felt in those regions. That she would proclaim her fresh departure by negotiating for the cession of a coaling station in the Persian Golf, as is reported from Paris, is, however, entirely unlikely. indeed, the statements issued on this subject from the French capital and published in London are described as a mare's- rest

The scheme is very thoroughly dealt with in the latest number of "The Spectator." Our contemporary thinks that in all probability we shall immediately be asked to prove the since- rity of our desire to be on good terms with Germany, and to establish a better understand- ing with her Government The test proposed will be our assent to the Baghdad Railway. n our opinion (says the "Spectator") our Govern- ment should most certainly do. nothing to oppose the making of that railway. We say now in the most absolute terms, as we said when the scheme was mooted some four years ago, that no railway can be laid on any part of the world's surface without benefit to Britain. Britain, as the greatest of trading nations, most be the better for more railways. Most foolishly, we attempted to prevent the cutting of the Suez Canal ; bat the Suez Canal was out, and proved of immense material benefit to Britain. In the same way, if the Baghdad Railway is made, it is certain to carry large quantities of British goods, and so to benefit British trade. Clearly, then, no obstacles should be placed by us—and we are convinced that none will be placed by us—in the way of the Baghdad Railway. When, however, as we expect will prove to be the case, we are not merely asked to refrain from throwing obstacles in the way of the railway, but are asked as a Government to sanction and patronise that railway officially, a very different question arises. What we objected to on the former occasion, and what we feel obliged to object to now, is the proposition that the name of the British Government should be placed, as it were, upon the prospectus of the Baghdad Railway, and that British investors should be asked to put their money into the scheme under the encouragement or moral guarantee of our Government That proposition is a very differ- ent matter, and seems to us one open to the very gravest objection.

Now, however, we are in effect told that we shall be guilty of an unfriendly act towards Germany if we do not change our practice in this respect, and, as we have said, allow the name of the British Government to be placed upon the prospectus of the Baghdad Railway. We cannot give the investor the right, if the railway fails as a speculation, to turn upon the British Government and say : "Yon gave us a moral guarantee for the investment of our money." Again, if the question of the Indian mail subsidies is raised, we do not think that the British Government ought to go further than to say that if, when the rail- way is built, it can be shown that three or four days can be saved by sending the mails by the Baghdad Railway, then no doubt we shall send them by that route, provided, of course, that the railway will give os reasonable terms. British mails must travel by the quickest route, granted that those who control the quickest route do not make "their terms too onerous.

The promoters of the Baghdad Railway should carry out their railway by an honest and straightforward appeal to the investors of the world, and not by any elaborate diplo- matic or financial hocus-pocus. There is plenty of money in Germany, in England, and in France for any and every sound commercial project. If a project is not reasonably sound commercially, it is better that the world should hear no more of it. Our hope, however, is hat the promoters of the Baghdad Railway, abandoning all diplomatic and financial finesse, will be able to get their money in the open market and build their railway . If they do, we have no doubt that British trade and commerce, in conjunction with the trade and commerce of the rest of the world, will im- mensely benefit thereby.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: Yesterday's plague bulletin records a fresh case and a death at Samalout.

div.head: The Regent.
div.p: H.E. Mustapha Pacha Fehmy will act as Regent during the absence of the Khedive in Europe.
Council of Ministers.
The Council of Ministers will let this afternoon at Ras-el-Tin Palace under the presidency of the Khedive.
Cattle Plague.
Our Fayoum Correspondent states that five fresh cases of cattle plague have occurred in the esbet Hadad in Kohfa village.
Coal Imports.
The imports of coal from January 1 to May 31 amounted to 541,953 tons, as against 361,183 tons during the same period last year.
Banquet to Slatin Pacha.
The members of the Legislative Council who were present at the inauguration of the Port Sudan-Atbara railway gave a banquet yester- day to Sir Rudolph von Slatin Pacha at the Grand Continental Hotel.
Alhambra Theater.

This evening, the ever-popular Boccaccio will be produced by the Italian operetta com- many. To-morrow, La Stiratrice will be given as a matinee and Il Diavolo in Corpo in the evening. The company are at present rehearsing Dalla terra alla Luna and Les Petis Brebis.
The "Statuto."

To-morrow being the Italian national fete of the "Statute," the Marquis Salvago-Raggi will hold a reception of the members of the Italian colony at 11 a.m. at the Italian Diplomatic Agency at Cairo. M. Monzani, Acting Consul General at Alexandria, will give a similar reception here.
Sale of Shoonah.

The Bavarian royal University of Munich has just sold, on advantageous conditions, to the Society Anonyme des Presses Libres Egyptiennes, a large shoonah which it pos- sessed at Minet-et-Bassal, Alexandria. It has also leased to the same company for 10 years an open space of ground of 2,106 square metres.
Hashish Smuggling.

The Coast Guard Administration confiscated yesterday a quality of hashish which a native boatman was attempting to smuggle though fate No. 6 on the Marina. The boatman was arrested. A Frenchman and another native were also attempting to smuggle a quantity of hashish yesterday when they were discover- ed by a coastguard in the Customs quarter.
Provincial Crime.

A gang of robbers has appeared at Ashmoun and is reported to have committed several brutal assaults. Another gang attacked a house at Al Gedided on the 27th inst. A scuffle ensued, and a native named Mahmoud Ibrahim Attia was killed. The murderer, Mahran Ali Said by name, was arrested by the other memebers of the gang and an enquiry opened by the police.
Mikado and Islam.

The rumor of the conversion of the Emperor of Japan to Islam has been revived by the native Press. A Tartar newspaper published in the Caucasus is responsible for the state- ment. "Al Lewa" remarks: "If the news is unconfirmed to-day there is nothing against its confirmation in the near future. Why should the Emperor Mutsohito not share the views of Napoleon I., the Great Emperor of the French ?"
Mohamed Zeki, el Din Seued, on of the ulema, writes to "Al Lewa" on this subject, offering to go to preach Islam to the Japanese provided that good food, accommodation, etc., are guaranteed him !

div.head: THE PILGRIMAGE
div.p: EMIR EJ HAJ's REPORT

According to a "Times" correspondent, the report of the Emir el Haj, Lewa Ibra- him Fathy Pacha, is highly satisfactory from every point of view, and bears ample testimony to the wisdom of the measures taken this year to safeguard the lives and property of Egyptian pilgrims from the lawless Bedouins of the Hed- jaz. The Jeddah-Mecca pilgrim road was well guarded this year by Turkish troops, only a few petty thefts being reported. Arafat, where pilgrims had been robbed and murdered in previous years, was held by a post of Ottoman regulars and Zaptiehs and was in consequence perfectly safe, and the Bedouins of this part of the Hedjaz, two tribes of whom has indulged in a regular engagement within sight of the headquarters of the Bali of the Hedjaz in 1904, had been cowed by the public execution at Mecca of several notorious brigands by the orders of Ali Pacha, the new Sherif of Mecca. Medina appears to have been quiet, but its Governor, fearing an attack by the Beni Harb should the escort take the Darb el Sultani (the Sultan's road), ordered it to follow another route known as the "Tarik el Tarif," on which little water was to be found, and which took four more days to traverse owing to the broken and rocky nature of the country. Dear Yambo el Nakhl there was some trouble with the Beni Ibrahim and El Sefkafah Bedouins, who has arrived too late to receive their share of the customary presents distributed to the chiefs of those tribes. But the pilgrims and escort reached Tambo safely, and of the 3,000 persons who accompanied the Mahman, soldiers and civilian members of the escort, pilgrims and camel drivers, not one fell a victim to the Bedouins. As far as one can judge from the report of the Emir el Haj, the increase of the Turkish garrisons in the Hedjaz and the vigour of the new Sherif have rendered the Bedouins who live between the coast and Arafat comparatively submissive. If the tribes in the Medina district are more restless, their days of brigandage are none the less numbered. The steady advance of the Hedjaz Railway, which is now, accord- ing to the latest news from Syria, being once more pushed rapidly towards Tebouk, brings with it the Turkish regular soldier and the Kurd, or Circassian Zaptieh, before whom the Bedouin has given way in Syria and Patraea. Elusive and wily as they are, the Bedouins of North Arabia and Syria are incapable of con- ducting or resisting an attack with any resolution- ion, and, though the Emir el Has reports that the Hedjaz tribes, who 15 years ago possessed no better fire-arms than long matchlocks and flint-lock muskets, are now armed to the extent of 50 per cent of their number with breechloaders, Mausers, and Martini Henrys for the most part, there is no reason to credit them with more military qualities than their northern kindred.

div.head: AKABA.
div.p: We hear that H.H.S. Nour el Bahr is leaving Suez fro Akaba this morning for the last time. Her commander and crew will probably feel an intense satisfaction at their departure from the lonely gulf, whose forbidding natural features they must now know by heart. The Frontier Commission is now working north of Akaba and the delimitation makes very satisfactory progress.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: H.H. the Khedive arrived at Ras-el Tin Palace from Montazah at 7.45 a.m. to-day for the last reception which his Highness will hold before his departure for Constantinople. We need not say that the reception was largely attended.
H.H. the Khedive gave a reception to Moslem ladies between 4 and 5 o'clock this afternoon.
As the Khedive's train was passing gate No. 21 on the Marina, it was stopped for a few moments by a carriage which had been left on the line and which has to be shunted.

Our Correspondent at Constantinople an- bounces that on Friday week, in the course of an audience after the Selamlik, Sir Nicholas O'Conor insistes on the recall of the Ottoman High Commissioner in Egypt.
We give this news with all reserve.

div.head: "AL UMMA" AGAIN!
div.p: In its issue of May 31 our amusing Pan- Islamic contemporary announces the arrival at Khartoum of the deputation sent by the Sultan Ali Dinar bringing the annual tribute paid by Dartour to the Sudan Government.

"Al Umma" remarks that if the Anglo- Egyptian Government of the Sudan believes that it is the suzerain of the ruler of Darfour, the future will undeceive it by proving that Ali Dinar is the vassal of Turkey and the faithful servant of the Caliph of Islam. Some jokes lose by repetition.

div.head: PAN-ISLAMISM.
div.p: ARTICLE BY MUSTAPHA PACHA KAMEL.

"Al Lewa" publishes the following as a leading article by Mustapha Pacha Kamel :- The European press has been dwelling during the last few days on the topic of Pan- Islamism, but many papers strayed from the path of accuracy when referring to the question- ion as if Pan-Islamism aimed at stirring ip Mohamedans against Christians, and bringing back such religious wars as those which in the past inflicted such disasters on the human race and did such serious harm to its civilisa- tion and prosperity. Such statements come only from the ignorant or fanatical whose object is to excite the European nations against Mohamedans. If Moslems sympathise with each other and require progress fro their com- unities and states, rejoicing at every laudable action that elevates their government and glorifies there Caliphate, they do not intend to upset the world, nor that the Moslems should stand together against the Christians: their ideal is an advance in prosperity, and a growth in civilisation, such as was attained by their forefathers and such as is now attained by the nations of Europe, America, and Japan. Had these Western writers been animated by a true and earnest love for the human race, to see the world enjoying progressive civilisation and propensity; if they had really desired this (as they claim) they would have been fain to welcome Pan-Islamism, which may enlighten three hundreds millions of men or give renewed life to one of the most vital and powerful members of the human body, and rect one of the most important pillars of the world. Some false prophets have taken upon themselves to point out that Pan-Islamism is dangerous to Moslems, and the Islam should not be mentioned except in religious matters. But they appear to have failed to realize that Islam teaches men, not only their religious cities, but how to seek prosperity and make the best use of their lives. Consequently it is impossible for a Mohamedan nation to advance from stage to stage of progress with- out being guided by the teachings of Islam. There is no reason why the rise and advance of the Mohamedan nations should not be effected by the same causes as those which caused their fall; and, such being the case, the wise man who advises the Egyptian people of the remedies necessary for their well-being can address his advice equally well to any other Moslem nation; since what appears to be use- ful to us is also useful to them. No wonder, then, if the Moslem nations of the world have the same sympathies and the same goal.

The enemies of Islam look with jealous eyes at all those Moslem peoples because of the great interest they take in the welfare of the Ottoman Government, with which they sum- pathise; but had they been in our position they would have not hesitated to follow our example. It is a matter of fact that every Moslem nation that loses its independence and falls in the hands of a European Power consoles itself by the existence of the Ottoman Government, which has taken on itself the duty of raising the Mohamedan faith, and to care and protect all Moslems who are everywhere attached to the Caliphate.

As for the Egyptians, there are many ties that bind them to the Ottoman Government; and in spite of the genuine patriotism and warm desire to maintain the independence of their country and secure self-government, they consider their country to be as much a part of the Ottoman Empire as Canada and Australia are of the British Empire. The local patriotism of the Egyptians would by no means prevent their having sincere sympathy and goodwill for their mother government. Pan- Islamism, consequently, is an essential bond of the Mohamedan peoples, especially the Egyp- trans; and those who look upon it as a dangerous policy are only attacking humanity with weapons of falsehood. The object of our aspiration is prosperity and upward progress, and we are waging no war except against ignorance and backwardness.

div.head: PORT SAID.
div.p: THE HARBOUR IMPROVEMENTS.

In his report on the trade of Port Said and Suez in 1905, Mr. Consul-General Cameron makes the following references to the con- templated improvements at Port Said :- With the opening of the ordinary-gauge Government Railway on June 1, 1904, a new era of prosperity has begun for Port said. The journey to Cairo has been shortened to five hours, and the number of daily trains has been increased both for goods and passengers, thus enabling the town to cope with the demands of traffic in connection with the thousands of tourists who pass through Port Said in the winter. A large tract of land has been recovered from Lake Menzaleh, and em- bankments have been made for the permanent station and depots.

During the next five years the barbour will have increased to more than twice its present area. Au extensive basin is being dredged on the eastern side of the Canal for the use of colliers and petroleum ships. When this is completed the Abbas basin (on the western side, now occupied by the colliers) will be available from vessels to load or discharge general cargo in connection with the interior of Egypt. At the same times, the Bassin Cherif on the western side is being doubles in size and deepened to 30 ft., and wharves and warehouses will be constructed without delay.

The Suez Canal Company's workshops will be removed to the eastern side of the harbor, where accommodation will be made for a new village for European andArabe workmen, and the tract of land at present occupied by the workshops will be dredged away and deepened, making a new large basin of the arsenal, with wharves reaching up to the railway station. The Menzaleh Canal and Navigation Com- pany have dredged a deep and wide channel across the shallow water of the lake, and established a service of ferry boats between Port Said (Karpooty) and Matarieh, the eastern point of the fertile province of Man- souah (Dakahlieh). The voyage would take about three hours, and, in co0operation with the light railway of the Society Anonyme des Chemins de Fer de la Basse Egypte, this route across the lake ought to prove of the greatest value in connecting Port Said with the north of the delta. It is poropseed to continue this channel as far as the station, and ultimately to connect it with a lock into the maritime canal, the present sweet-water canal passing under the channel by means of a syphon.

Another most important improvement now under consideration for contract is the renewal of the older eastern breakwater and its conti- nuation towards the western breakwater, so as to protect the shipping in harbour during the gales in winter.
Substantial progress is being made in nearly all these items above mentioned, and there is no doubt that within the next few years the commercial area of this harbour will have been doubled.

div.head: M. GENNADIS' DEPARTURE.
div.p: M. Gennadis, Hellenic Diplomatic Agent and Consul-General, who has retires, officially notified the British Agency of his recall on the 28th May. Lord Cromer acknowledged the communication in the following terms: "My dear Colleague, - In acknowledging receipt of the letters dated the 28th May, in which you have kindly informed me of your departure from Egypt, I avail myself of the opportunity to assure you of the since- city with which I reciprocate the friendly sentiments you have had the goodness to express regarding myself. I still experience a real pleasure in always keeping the most agreeable recollection of the relations which have existed between us during the period of your sojourn in Egypt, the frank and cordial nature of which has on several occasion so greatly facilitated the accomplishment of our mutual ask. - CROMER"

div.head: NEW MOTOR COMPANY
div.p: The prospectus of the Egyptian Motor Trac- ion Co., which will be published on tuesday next, is a model of brevity. Here it is in its en- tirety :- La Society a pour ajet l'exploitation de tous mayen de transport de persons et de marchandises et d'objets quelconques dans la ville d'Alexandrie, ses alentours et sa banlieu et principlalement l'exterprise et l'exploitation dun service d'omnibus automobiles." The company, as already stated, has been formed with a capital of £60,000 divided into 15,000 shares of £4 each, of which 5,000 are now offered to the public at par. The subscription list will be open at the Anglo0Egyptian Bank, Limited, Cairo and Alexandria, at 8.30 a.m. on Monday and will close at noon the same day. The members of the board are Messrs. Etienne Delta (chairman), Nicholas Paraske- was (vice-chairman), Edgar Giglio, Alfred Suares, and Clement Suares.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions ex- pressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit - within certain necessary limits - free discussion.

div.head: THE SULTAN'S WILES.
div.p: To the editor of the "Egyptian Gazette." Dear Sir, - A "Daily Telegraph" correspon- dance from Washington is reproduced in your yesterday's issue stating that Abdul Hamid has been left up to this day in ignorance of the death of President McKinley because no one dare inform him of the assassination of the latter.

It is quite true that any news of this kind comes as a terrible shock to abdul Hamid, who himself lives in perpetual terror of violent death, and has even shaped all his internal policy under the influence of this mono- maniacal idea. But to say that he does not know that McKinley fell a victim to Anar- schism is manifestly absurd. We might as well be told that he has been kept in the dark concerning the fate of Pres. Carnot, king Umberto, and the Empress Elisabeth, and that he believes he is still dealing with their predecessors.

So far from it bing the case that his entourage fine it advisable to deceive him in connection with such events, admitting this to be possible, is not Abdul Hamid in personal communication with the Ambassa- fors accréditiez to his Court, who converse with him through their own interpreters ? Not a minute is wasted by the responsible official in communicating the evil tidings. Woe betide him if there is any loss of time. It is not generally known that Abdul Hamid sees in every attempt on the life of a ruler a source from which to draw new inspiration for the preservation of his own life against the expected attacks of the regicide. I would add that the only books his 'lecteur' has orders to read to him are detective stories specially translated for him or composed by one of his courtiers on the basis of data provided by his Majesty himself. - Yours faithfully,
A. DE BILINSKI.
Cairo, June 1.

div.head: WHAT IS IT?
div.p: Cairo, 1st June.
Director of the news-paper E.G. Esq. This is the text of a telegram sent by us to the general manager of the E.S.R. please do good and publish it in your kind paper and thanks :-
Major Johnstone, G.M.E.S.R.
Cairo (Special).

You have kindly promised to equitably improve our distressing case. We hope that such perspi- cuous poor statement, manifest lamentable condi- tion, incomprehensible painful wretchedness, and miserable luck for which we are bitterly weeping, loudly screeming, and grieving, will attract your kind attention to help us and to wheel your mer- civil heart to assist us by the word we hope it will constantly be kept. - All Traffic Pupils Egypt- ian State Railways.
For them all, yours obedient. MOH. KEMA.

div.head: THE WAR OFFICE AND MR. HOYNE
div.p: "Truth" makes the following remarks on the case of Staff Sergeant-Major HOYLE. We hope they will have some effect :- "Not long ago a good deal was heard about an agitation in Ireland to discourage recruit- ing for the Army, and if I remember rightly one or two persons were prosecuted for pub- lishing false and malicious statements regard- ing the Army. I doubt, however, whether the wildest abuse of the bitterest anti-English agitators would do the Army anything like so much harm as the following letter which was addressed to the Clerk of Kilkenny Guar- dians :-
Royal Victoria Hospital, Netley
April 30th, 1906.

Sir, - I am directed to inform you that No. 18005, Staff-Sergeant-Major James Maher Hoynel, late Army Service Corps, a helpless discharged soldier, will be sent to the care of the union authorities, Kilkenny, on tuesday rect, the 8th pros. He was born in the parish of St. Mary, Kilkenny; enlisted for the Army at the Curragh Camp on October 2nd, 188. Will you kindly inform me as early as possible the name of the nearest railway station to the union ?
I am, Sir,
Your obedient Servant,
GEORGE A. SIMMS,
Lieut.-Col. R.A.M.C.

"The letter was discussed at the last meeting of the Guardians, and they passed a resolution refusing to receive Hoyne in the workhouse on the ground that the War Office ought to make some better provision for him. With this everybody outside the War Office will agree. Here is a soldier who has served his country for twenty one years - served so well that he has risen to the rank of Staff-Sergeant- Major. He is now a helpless invalid, and so his grateful country, as mis-represented by military officialfdom, proposes to pack him off to the workhouse of his native parish. Presumably the man is entitled to a pension, and surely a place could be found for him in some hospital or home for old soldiers."

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: General Valeriano Weyler y Nicolau, Marquis of Teneriffe, who (as reported by Reuter to-day) was seriously injured in the bomb explosion at Madrid, is the possessor of many home and foreign decorations. He was Minister of War in the Liberal Government presided over by Sagasta, and holds the same position in the present Government. Born at Palma of Mallorea (Baleares) on Septemper 17, 1838, he is the son of Fernando Weyler y Lavina, Genereal Inspector of the Military Sanitary Body. He has been successively commander-in-chief of the Canary Island, Baleares, the Philippines, Burgos Navarra, Vascongados, Catalusia, Cuba, and Madrid ; and went through the campaigns of Santo Domingo and Cuba twice, besides taking part in the civil was in the north of Spain and the fighting in Mindanoa Island. He has the reputation of neither smoking nor drinking spirits, and is not fond of bull- fighting, while he cares little for music, the theatre or any other public recreations. He has written some fragments of his official memoirs, many prologues of books, and several parliamentary speeches.
Mr. P. Machell, Adviser at the Ministry of the Interior, arrived at Alexandria this morning from Cairo.
Colonel O. Todd, R.A.M.C., is leaving for Bombay by the R.I.M.T. Dufferin, sailing from Port Said on the 9th inst.
During the absence of Major R. Percy Smith, R.G.A., on leave, Left.-Col. Campbell, R.H.A., will perform the duties of C.R.A., Egypt.
Leave of absence on private affairs, with permission to travel in France and Switzerland, has been granted to Captain M.P.E. Lonsdale, 1st Royal Dublin Fusiliers, from July 4 to October 3.
At the recent "Nilotic Arabic" Service Examination held in Uganda Lieutenant S.W. ratlins and Dr. L.S. Lowsley were successful competitors.
Mr. and Mrs. B.S. Seed and family are leaving Port Said by the S.S. Macedonia for England on Monday next.

Mr. Davidson, the ex-engineer of the Fayoum Light Railway Company, left the Fayoum yesterday for Port Said, where he has obtained an appointment with the Menzaleh Canal and Navigation Company. Mr. and Mrs. Davidson leave behind them nay friends in the Fayoum.

div.head:
THE MADRID OUTRAGE.
KING ALFONSO'S SANG-FROID.
PLOT HATCHED IN LONDON.
24 PEOPLE KILLED.
GENERAL WEYLER AMONG INJURED.

div.p: After the explosion, King Alfonso stood up as if to protect Princess Ena. He smilingly sainted the alarmed public, and assisted the Princess to alight. The bomb, which was of polished steel, burst in the air, killing two aristocratic occupants of a balcony. The people, were infuriated, threatening tc lynch foreigners. A Catalan named Manne Duran has been arrested, and is believed to be the author of the outrage. Another acount describes an Italian, who escaped. (Reuter)
It is stated that the Madrid authorities asked the Spanish Embassy yesterday tc enquire whether the Anarchist plot bad been hatched here. (Reuter)

According to the latest information, three officers, seven soldiers, and five spectators were killed, and a hundred people injured including General Weyler, whose condition is serious. Princess Ena is indisposed. The festivi- ties continue. Twenty arrests have been made, but it is believed that the actual perpetrator has so far escaped, although he is known. King Alfonso and his Ministers will attend the funeral of the victims.

Their Majesties motored, unescorted, through the city in the forenoon. They received a tremendous ovation, crowds running in streams, on either side, delirious with enthusiasm. t Five of the persons injured by the explosion died to-day.
There are indications that the outrage was hatched by Anarchists in London, and the most active investigations are being made there. (Reuter)
The police have arrested an Englishman, named Hamilton, as an accomplice. The "Epoca" states that the number of killed is 13 military and 11 civilians. (Havas)
M. Falliéres has telegraphed his sympathies to King Alfonso.
The Chamber of Deputies and the Senate stigmatised the Madrid outrage. (Havas)

div.head:
THE NATAL CAMPAIGN.
ASSISTANCE OP POWERFUL CHIEF.

div.p: The Natal Government has accepted the assistance of Silwane, the most powerful chief in Natal. A thousand of his men start.for the front immediately. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE DUMA IN DESPAIR.
MANIFESTO TO WORKERS

div.p: Duma.—Speeches yesterday were expressive of anger and despair at the attitude of the Government. The Labourite deputies issued a manifesto calling on workers to organise their forces to assist the Duma in the conflict with the Government. (Reuter)

div.head:
TEH MOROCCO CRISIS.
WHAT IT COST FRANCE.

div.p: It is announced that France spent £8,000,000 on military preparations in connection with the Morocco crisis, hence the heavy deficit shown in the Budget. (Reuter)

div.head:
FUNERAL OF IBSEN.
KING AND MINISTRY PRESENT.

div.p: Henrik Ibsen was buried to day in the pre- sence of a peat concourse of people. The King and the Ministry were present. (Reuter)
A gale and a heavy sea are imperilling the Montagu. Salvage operations have been sus- pended. (Reuter)
M. Brisson has been elected provisional President of the Chamber by 398 votes. (H.)
Oaks Stakes. 1. Keystone II. 2. Gold Rioch. 3. Snow Glory. (Reuter)

div.head: ARCHITECTURE AND PROGRESS
div.p: MR. WILLIAM'S LECTURE.
(Continued from Wednesday.)

In some articles which, last December, I had the honor of contributing to the "Gazette" mention was made of the division of Architecture into two broad classes, namely, the organic and inorganic. I was told by a scholastic friend that those articles were rather too technical - and il- lustration of the difficulty under which we achi- tests suffer. Therms fail us. Our shop and studio phrases have become common-places in our mouths and it is with difficulty that we can find each other and more general terms. Mr. Reginald Blomfield, the well-known archi- textural writer, in the preface to his interesting "Studies in Architecture", mentions such diffi- cuties, stating that "the result has been that architecture, considered as an art, had dropped out of the main stream of educated thought," but he adds:- "After all the vital interest of architecture is the human interest," with which we cannot but agree, but while we agree we are bound to admit, that if anything of human interest has dropped out of the "stream of educated thought."

That this one point should be architecture is as strange as it is true. There never was a time when the great architectural works of Egypt, of Greece, of Rome, of Europe, and the world generally were so much viewed as at present; never before were these works so be-photographed, drawn, and illustrated; never were handbooks and guidebooks to the architectural glories of the world so plentiful, and never were facilities of access to and for study of these buildings so easy an so much availed of as at the present time. To proceed with our two classes of archi- lecture. The inorganic form of architecture means, simply, the posing of masses of materials one upon another, the stability of the resultant structure depending upon sheer weight and mass alone. A pyramid is a simple form, and two columns supporting a beam is a more complex form of inorganic building. All build- ings in some measure partake of both forms, but broadly and generally the Egyptian and Greek styles are inorganic.

The other form, the organic, is distinguished by the arch. The Egyptians used the arch when constructing in brick, but neither they nor the Greeks, who followed them, developed this form of architecture. It was left to the Etruscans and the Romans to carry on this development. These famous builders seized upon the arch and developed it in a masterly fashion. They discovered the means of orga- rising material. With black of comparatively small size, brick or aggregate of concrete, they spanned spaces which far exceeded those covered by the great stone slabs of the Egyp- trans. Under the hands of the Byzantine buil- dress this form of building was developed still further and in the 13th and 14th centuries the Gothic builder brought it to a state of perfection. The short definition then would run: Columns and beams are inorganic; ar- ches and domes are organic.

Now let us for a moment consider the inor- ganic architecture of the Greeks. In the hands of the Greek master masons, the trabeated, or column and beam, or inorganic architec- sure, was brought to perfection. The columns were beautiful in form and proportion and became the main feature. As it left the chisel of these wonderful masons, the column became too beautiful to be hidden. Like everything else that is beautiful and good it had to be brought to the light. It was not to serve as a mere post, as in the semi-light of an Egyptian temple, but through itself beautiful, was made to carry the more beautiful sculpture of the Greek tympanums.

The Egyptian used his column primarily to support the ends of his roof slabs, which were too short to reach from wall to wall. True, he arranged his columns in two or more symetri- cal rows, dividing his great walls into naves and aisles. He also decorate his column most beautifully with colour. His building, in its simplicity, was a rectangle formed of massive walls on the exterior and rows of columns in the interior for the support of his roof. The Greeks reversed this order, as in the case of the Theseum at Athens. They built a cell or naos as a nucleus and surrounded the walls of it with one or more rows of columns, something like a verandah. They railed their buildings in with beautiful columns.

Although the Greeks also used the columns in the interior of their buildings the column became principally an external feature; and in accordance with its proportion, the form of its base, or the absence of a base, the decora- ion of its capital and contour of its mouldings, it became the index for the discrimination of the style of a building.

The column is no longer a useful detail of architecture to be used when required, but has become the domineering and obtrusive master upon all occasions. The column is much worshipped in Alexandria and often without reason. A column is the sign and seal of respec- tability. It is to be seen in all kinds of positions; sometimes without a foundation, at others without a head and occasionally has to be supplied with elaborate bracketing to hold it up. In nine cases out of ten it is probably incongruous and unnecessary. If it cannot be had in polished marble it will be built of soft brick and softer Mex stone, plastered over and painted to look like the finest vert antique. It should not be understood here that objection is offered to the painting of wood or stone; on the contrary, the practice of the ancients may often be followed with pleasing results in this beautiful climate. The Egyptians, Greeks, Romans, and Venetians painted their buildings on a large scale, but not to deceive, at least in their noblest days. "In a word," says Mr. Maspero, "paint- ing was in Egypt the mere humble servant of architecture and sculpture."

"What are you to to?" I was asked by a learned friend. "If you cannot have the rea- city ten you must have good imitation." By no means. If you cannot have granite or marble, then use sandstone, or Marseilles brick, or if you cannot do this and must build in soft Mex stone, plaster and paint it if you like. Use paint both as a perspective and as a decoration if you think well, but do not let your columns or the sides go your staircases tell an untruth to every visitor who honours you house with a visit. (To be continued)

div.head: CAPTURED BY BRIGANDS IN MACEDONIA.
div.p: Mr. Philip Martin Wills, who las July was captured by brigands in Macedonia, recently arrived in England, and has been relating his experiences. He states that he was born of British parents in Constantinople and served in South Africa. Subsequently he entered the service of the Regie de Tabac, the tobacco monopoly in Turkey. He was controller of the tobacco cultivation in the vilayet of Monastir in Macedonia. Early in July las he was cap- tired by Bulgarian brigands. He was taken to the mountains, where he was forced to write a letter to the chief of the Regie de Tabac, enclosing letters to the Consul at Monastir and to his own brother. These letter were not delivered. Mr. Wills was also forced to write other letters to the Consul direct and these were delivered. In them a demand was made for a ransom of 6,000 Turkish liras. The Consul, upon receipt of the letters, went to the Turkish authorities, who said that Mr. Wills was no doubt in league with the brigands. About two and a half monts after the capture Mr. Wills had his left ear cut off, and this was sent in a letter to the Consul at Monastir, with a demand that the ransom should be forwarded, or the other ear and the nose of the captive would be cut off and sent. Upon this, Mr. Graves, the English Consul General for Salonika, was sent to Monastir to see what could be done, but the negotiations with the brigands failed. Even- tally, after such ill-treatment, Mr. Wills escaped on November 12 and found his way to a village name Sarisvor. The Turkish authorities took Mr. Wills to Resna, whence the commandant of gendarmerie, who had been sent after him, took him to Monastir. Here, at the Vali's house, the British Acting Vice-Consul met him and took him to the British Consulate. He remained there 15 days, and Mr. Wills alleges that, in the meantime, the Turkish authorities got the people at Resna with whom Mr. Wills has lodged after his escape to make a false declaration that a month previously he had come to the place fully armed as a brigand and had slept the night there. This Mr. Wills emphatically denies, and says he has proved to the satisfaction of the British Consulate that it was impossible for him to have been there at the time. A letter, he says, is in the hands of the British Consulate at Monastir, signed by the gendarmerie, bribing these people to make the declaration, the falseness of which they have since admitted. As certain papers have cast a doubt upon Mr. Will's bona fides, he has made the above statement.

div.head: Circulaire H. de Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES

Le Caire, Vendredi 1er Juin. A Londres, le Consolidé anglais est resté invarié hier à 90. L'Unifiée a baissé de 1er & 104 1/8. La National Bank a clotnré à son cours précédent, soit 26, de même que l'Agri- cole à 9 7/8 et la Daira à 17 1/2. La Delta Land a perdu 1/8 à 12. A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier Egyptien est restée immobile à 772. La Banque d'Athènes est en avance de 1 franc a. 151. * * * Ici, nous avons en, ce matin, un marché relativement ferme, avec assez de transactions. L'animation s'est portée principalement sur les Egyptian Hotels, qui ont en les honneurs de la séance, ainsi que sur les Delta Land. Le compartiment des Banques a été calme. La National Bank a clôturé à SG et l'Agricole à 9 3/4-25/32. La Banque d'Orient s'est raf- fermie à 132. Le Comptoir Financier a encore fléchi à 5 9/16 l'action ancienne et 5 7/16 la nouvelle. L'action Crédit Foncier a progressé à 776 et l'obligation à lots 1886 à 322-323. La Daïra a gagné 1/16 a 17 1/4. La Delta Light a faibli à 12 et le Wardan Estate a 5 15/16. La Nile Land a rétrogradé à 13 3/4. L'action Immobilière s'est raffermie à 375. L'action Enterprise and Development a avancé à 11 15/16-12. L'action Ciments est tombée à 60 ; la part de dividende à 16. Les Omnibus du Caire se sont inscrits à 26 3/4-27. Dans le groupe des Hôtels, les Baehler en excellente tendance, ont haussé de 5 3/16 à 5 7/16, gagnant 1/4 de livre, pour clôturer à 6 3/8, acheteurs. Les Nungovich ont regagné 1/8 à 16 13/16 l'action ancienne et 14 7/8 15/16 la nouvelle. Les Upper Egypt ont reconquis 1/16 à 4 3/8. Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land ont avancé & 4 1/16. Les Hooker sont restés à 1 3/32. Les Abdy ont été demandés à 1 11/3?. Lee Cotton Mills ont été cotés 6 sh., et les Sucreries entre 19 et 20. * * * Ainsi que nous l'avions déjà annoncé dans notre Circulaire d'avant hier, le marché des valeurs sera fermé demain et lundi prochain à l'occasion des fêtes de Pentecôte. Il y aura également cessation d'affaires sur le marché des contrats en ces deux jours, ainsi que le vendredi 8 et le samedi 9 Juin par suite des jours fériés de Liverpool. Le prochain numéro de notre Circulaire paraîtra le mardi 5 Juin. * * * On annonce d'Alexandrie le retour du baron de Kusel bey, directeur-général de l'Egyptian Trust and Investment Ltd. (Glymenopoulo). Le baron de Kusel bey revient d'Angleterre, où il avait été délégué par le comité de direc- tion local pour conférer avec le Board de Lon- dres sur les intérêts do la Société à l'approche de la première assemblée générale ordinaire. On rapporte que la question da dividende, qui formait l'une des principales affaires a discuter, aurait été définitivement tranchée. * * * L'assemblée extraordinaire des actionnaires de l'Agricultural Bank of Egypt, convoquée pour approuver la modification proposée a l'article 41 des Statuts, se tiendra cet après- midi, à 4 heures, a la National Bank of Egypt. * * * L'assemblée générale ordinaire des action- naires de la Société des Eaux de Tantah a été tenue, hier danB l'après midi, au siège social au Caire. Les comptes et le bilan de l'exercice 1905 ont été approuvés. Il a été décidé de payer un dividende de 6 1/2 pour cent. * * * MM. H. de Vries et Bontigny Agents de change se chargent de l'exécution de tous ordres de Bourse (valeurs et marchandises) sur les marchés de Londres, Paris, Bruxelles, Anvers, Liverpool et New York. La Circulaire quotidienne de la maison est envoyée sur demande.

div.head: MENAGERIE MASSERINI.
div.p: La ménagerie continue ses représentation avec le même succès. Hier none avons assisté a la danse du feu, ou mieux la danse serpentine, dans la cage aux lions. Il faut là un réel courage ; affronter des animaux feroces fouet et fourche en main n'est certes point aisé, mais danser devant e x, n'ayant pour arme qu'un voile de telle demande un sang froid et an mépris du danger dont nous félicitons Madame Massserini. La ménagerie vient de recevoir du Soudan de charmants lionceaux que M. Masserini va mettre à l'élevage et nous présentera dans quelques jours ainsi qn'un léopard qu'il est en train de dresser.

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier DE "L'EGYPTIAN GAZETTE"
div.p: Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" parait chaque Samedi à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs ; les der- nières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publi- cation : des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc. L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste ; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sas. Pour de plus amples informations, s'adresser an directeur de l' "Egyptian Gazette".

div.head: Société Internationale des Employés D'ALEXANDRIE.
div.p: Siège Social Rub Mosquée Attarine No. 21
BUREAU DE PLACEMENT

Une maison du Caire demande un employé sérieux âgé de 22 à 30 ans connaissant le français et l'anglais, si possible aussi l'arabe. Appointeront 8£ poor début; il faut savoir également écrire à la machine. Une maison de la ville demande n employé comme caissier on encaisseur, offrant de bonnes références et une garantie de 1000£. Une maison de Nonveautés (importante) demande un commis aux écritures. Comptable expérimenté ayant des heures disponibles désire tenir des Livres 06 donner des leçons à des conditions avantageuses. Bennes références. Une grande maison anglaise de commerce à Alexandrie demande un caissier apprenti connaissant l'anglais. La même maison demande an bon employé connaissant aussi l'anglais pour sa succursale au Caire. Une maison de Nouveautés demande an sons- chef bonnetier. Une grande maison de Nouveautés d'Alexan- drie demande un aide comptable connaissant bien l'allemand. Une antre grande maison de détail demande un employé connaissant très bien le rayon chemiserie et bonneterie, et sachant le fran- çais et l'italien. Très belle situation. Une maison de Port-Saïd demande un jeune homme connaissant bien le travail de bureau en général, les langues allemande et française, et si possible quelques notions d'anglais ; il aurait à assister à l'expédition des bateaux comme "shipping clerk." Deux, employés de grande Maison de Banque, disposant de quelques heures par jour, demandent à tenir des livres de commerce. Bonne références. Un bon placier, an besoin comptable, connais- sant le français, l'italien, l'allemand, l'arabe et le turc demande emploi. Caissier comptable connaissant le français, l'anglais, le grec, le turc et l'arménien de- mande emploi. On demande un employé pour diriger impri- merie. Un bon encaisseur, connaissant la vente des drogueries, cherche place, bonnes références. Un professeur d'escrime demande place et au besoin à donner des leçons domicile. N.B.— Pour tons renseignements s'adresser an Siège Social de la Société, Rue Mosquée Attarine No. 21. div.head: REVUE COMMERCIALE
div.p: Cotons.

Irregularite et indecision, tels sont les deux mots qui dépeignent le mieux l'état de notre marche pendant la semaine qui vient de finir. Il ne faudrait pourtant pas trop se plaindre de cette allure, car sans elle et les fréquentes fluctuations soudaines et presque toujours tres rapides sur la vieille récolté qu'elle nous a values, l'intérêt aurait complètement manque et l'atention serial peut être restée entière- ment concentrée sur le Novembre seul, ce qui aurait été insuffisant. Au fond cependant, il n'y a rien eu d'extraordinaire, mais ce qu'il y a de remarquable a relever, c'est qu'en definitive c'est la fermeté qui a fini par prévaloir et cela en debit des nouvelles de l'etranger et de la baisse marquee de l'americain, circonstance qui pour le moins aurait du contrecarrer la dernière reprise. En somme, la speculation a montre encore une fois qu'elle n'avait fait que se recueillir pour mieux agir ensuit, et s'est uniquement en sachant mettre a profit les causes purement locales, qui lui ont été favorables, qu'elle a reuse dans ses efforts a soutenu les cours. Maintenant, il ne faudrait pas trop se hater a conclure par la qu'elle est a meme de con- tinuer fans cette voie pour longtemps et que le succès viendra toujours lui sourire, ca d'un autre cote le découvert sur Juillet n'existe pas et comme l'aencheance approche, elle est bien forcee de tourner les yeux vers le commerce d'exportation, en dehors duquel il n'y a pas de salut, cette année, lorsqu'il devra s'agir de la ;liquidation finale. En effet, nos exportateurs sont aujourd'hui les seuls vendeurs sérieux de contrats contre leur stock, et si un réveil de la demande de la part de la consommation ne survient pas d'ici a quelques jours pour les aider a écouler la marchandise au dehors, il y aura selon toute apparence, des le premeier jour du mois prochain, une emission generale de filieres que, d'aucune façon, les détenteurs de Juillet non professionnels ne peuvent souhaiter. Il est certain qu'a un certain prix la filature, qui pour le moment se repose sur les achats a bon marche qu'elle a faits en dernier lieu, re- viendra au marche pour combler les besoins qu'elle peut encore avoir a couvrir pour le res- tant de la saison, et, par consequent, une de- bandage, au vrai sens du mot, ne semble guère probable; mais, d'autre part aussi, une hausse comme l'entendent nos spéculateurs n'est plus possible, surtout si, au lieu de simplement soutenir, il leur prenait la fantaisie de pousser les cours d'une manière factice er inconsidérée. Ce qui precede ne s'applique pas a la nou- velle recolte, etant donne que la situation de celle ci est tout a fait différent te de celle du Juillet, le deport entre le Novembre et ce der- nier étant de près de 5 tallaris, fait qui est de nature a retarder toute baisse sérieuse jusqu'a ce que les cours de l'Américain viennent régler les nôtres. Aussi, l'opinion prédominante est- elle que l'on peut soutenir encore pendant quelque temps le Novembre et d'autant plus facilement que ces temps derniers la filature a fini par s'y intéresser. Certes, ses achats n'ont pas eu une grande importance, mais en somme elle a opéré sur Octobre a December et cela fournit un certain appui aux intéressés a la hausse, sans pourtant les aider a faire mous- ser les prix, attendu que l'interieur de son cote continue a vendre et ferment aux exporta- leurs de trouver chez le cultivateur une partie de leur couverture. En resume, le niveau actuel du Novembre n'est pas trop risque et la specu- latin en s'y engagement ne s'expose pas a de grands déboires.

Ceci dit en guise d'entree en matière et en meme temps comme conclusion de ce que nous pensons, passons a la revue du marche. La fermete constatee a la cloture de cen- dread dernier, s'est accentuée le lendemain et quoique le maximum de 21 3/4 pratique dans la matinee n'ait pu être maintenu, la seance n'en a pas moins fini sur la cote de 21 19/32, soit avec une avance de 7/32.

En réalité cela a paru être un indice de fai- blesse, mais une propagande acharnée faite par les détenteurs du Juillet a attire une foule d'acheteurs a l'ouverture de lundi et comme premier cours il a été feit 21 13/16. Seulement, quelques offres sérieuses ayant de suite calme les principaux meneurs, la puce vint aux oreilles des nouvelles recrues et au lieu de finir par être la victime des chauffeurs qui ne cher- chaient qu'a leur passer leurs paquets ils pas- seront immédiatement dans le camp oppose, ce qui a en pour effet de nous faire reculer de 7/16 de taller en nous rament a notre point de depart qui avait été de 21 3/8.

Les deux jours suivants, la tenue e été en- core moins brillante et les deux matinees ont fini a 21 1/16; mais comme a ce niveau les ven- deurs se faisaient rares, leurs adversaires ont pu facilement réagirez et comme résultat le Juillet est remonte a 28 1/2 pour finir aujourd'hui a 21/716.
En definitive c'est 1/16 de gagne et cela n'est pas du tout mal si l'on tient compte de l'abs- mention du commerce et de la baisse de l'Ame- ricin qui aurait du tout au moins contrecarrer la reprise.

Le Novembre, malgré les attaques dont il a été l'objet, a eu une tenue bien plus satis- faisante et c'est a peine s'il a touche le cours de 16 23/32 au plus bas; toutefois, comme cloture finale, nous le trouvons a 16 25/32, soit 1/16 au-dessous de la semaine passée. Sous le rapport de l'activite, par contre, il n'a rien laisse a desirer, ce qui s'explique par le fait que l'interet concentre sur lui est désor- mais colossal.
Le marche du disponible, tout en restant sootenu a curse des contrats, a été d'un calme plat parfait, tant a cause du marque de de- mande, que du peu de choix qu'offre la mar- chandise a la vente.

Quant aux prix, li résulte de la cote officielle eatable ce matin, que les Mit Affifi et les pro- dances Haute-Egypte sont en hausse de 1/4 de taller, mais en réalité ce n'est qu'a cause des contrats que cette modification a été apportee.

Du cote des exportations, il y a eu surprise agreeable pour les haussier a laquelle il faut attribuer le soutien de ce matin: Depassant toute prevision, le total de la semaine a fini par atteindre 9,500 Balles contre 9,600 l'an- nee dernière. Au fond l'augmentation n'a eu lieu qu'au detriment du chiffre reconsidérer pour la premiere semaine Juin, mais en attendant cela ne l'a pas empêchée de produire son effet. Comme stock, nous sommes maintenant a contras 716.000 contre contrats 1.273,000, soit une nouvelle augmentation de cantars 22.000 dans le deficit relever la semaine passée et une autre amelioration de la position statique en favenr des haussiers.

Liverpool, n'a guère été chaud pour les egyptiens avec ses ventes atteignant a peine 1300 balles pours la semaine; par contre, du cote des prix, il y a a enregistre une hausse de 1/8 sur le spot, de 4/64 sur le Juin et le Juillet et de 2/64 sur le Novembre qui ont cloture respectivement a 10 5/8 et 10 10/64; 9 62/64 et 8 50/64.

Sur les américains disponibles il y a eu aussi peu d'activite et quant aux cours nous les trouvons en baisse de 18 points sur le spot, de 21 sur le Juillet Aout et de 16 pour l'Octobre Novembre. Apres tout, ce recul est encore infe- rieur a celui qui s'est vérifié a New York a la suite de la liquidation du groupe haussier de la position sur l'ancienne récolté.

On dit que cette liquidation n'a d'autre but que de permettre a Price et consorts de s'inte- lesser plus largement a la nouvelle récolte qui leur offre un plus grand champ d'action. Cela pent être vrai, mais en memetempsne pourrait- on pas croire qu'en vue d'un rapport défavo- table a leurs interests du Bureau d'Agriculture, ils ont voulu se reserver la possiblilire d; aider éventuellement a l'écrasement des cours avant de commencer leurs achats out leurs rachats sur la prochaine récolte ?

Le rapport est anxieusement attendu pour le 4 courant et les derniers pronostics feraient croire qu'il sera baissier. En attendant, et pour commencer nous avons l'estimation de la superficie ensemencée donneaujourd'hui meme par le Chronicle de New York wui est de 31,500,000 Acres, contre 28,200,000 l'annee dernière. Quelques intéressés ont beau cabler que la baisse a dit son dernier not; avec des chiffres pareils, sils venaient a être confirmes, nous pourrions bien reculer encore et les con- tinuelles offres de Sud ne sont nullement de nature a tranquilliser a ce sujet.

Chez nous, il n'y a rien de particulier a dires quant a la marche de la récolte et si nos lectures desiring quelques details, ils les trouveront dans le Resume de Mai de la Produce Association que nous publions plus lion.

div.head: Graines de Coton
div.p: Malgré les petits arrivages, le cours du disponible avaient baisse au commencement de la semaine et pour un moment nous étions tombes a P.T. 68; mais comme les exporta- tons ont fini par se developper un peu et que les contrats se sont relevés a leur tour, il y a eu reprise ces deux dernièrs jours et c'est a 70 que la semaine a fini.
A moins de circonstances imprévues, une ame- libration ultérieure semble probable pour la semaine prochaine a cause des embarquements qui ont tout a fait l'air de vouloir atteindre 80.000 Ardebs.

Par suite de manipulations baissières, le Juillet était tombe a P.T. 69 3/4, mais une contre attaque vigoureuse de haussiers n'a pas tarde a le faire remonter a P.T. 71 3/4; toutefois, comme clôture de la semaine, nous le trouvons a 71.- Les chances restent ce- pendant favorables, car le juin est rare sur le marche et selon toute apparence il n'y aura pas de grosse filière pour venir peser ou produire meme un désarroi passager. Hull a montre en passant des vellxites des baisse, t avait réduit son prix a £ 6 13/9, mais devant notre fermete, il offre de nou- veau £ 6 15/— Alexandrie damnée davantage et pour peu que notre marche ne montre pas de la faiblesse, lAngleterre finira par se laisser forcer la main un petit pen.
L'Angleterre n'a rien fait encore en nouvelle revolts, mais on a fini par parler d'un prix quelconque et celui mentienne en dernier lieu a été de £ 6 3/9 pour le novembre janvier.
Ici les contrats 3 mois n'ont pas été bien actifs, mais au fond ils sont restes soutenus, avec ds fluctuations de peu d; importance. Le dornier cours est P.T. 3/4.

div.head: Feves.
div.p: La penurie des arrivages continue a em- pêcher les affaires en disponible et par couse- quest comme prix il n'y a que celui de la consommation locale, qui est de 118 a 120, que l'on puisse donner.
Les contrats ont été pousses a P.T. 120, mais la cote est nominale ou imaginaire, car on ne voit pas trop qui pourrait s'intéresser a l'article dans ces conditions, si ce n'est comme vendeur.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA GENERAL PRODUCE ASSOCIATION.
div.p: Resume Des Réponses Reçues En Mai 1906.

La temperature en Mai a ete un peu trop fraiche, surtout dans la premiere moitie du mois, et continue a être irrégulière. Le développement de la plante s'en est ressenti et jusqu'ici l'on constate un retard presque general dans son avancement. Neanmoins, l'état des jeunes cotonniers sem- ble sain et la plupart de nos correspondants esperente qu'avec un peu plus de chaleurs ils pourront regagner une grande partie du retard. Les réensemencements, plus nombreux que l'annee dernier, cont partout termines. L'eau et suffisante et aucune plainte n'a été entendue jusqu'a present.

De rares apparitions de vers ont été signalées dans quelques districts isoles, mais rien de serious et aucum begat ne s'est produit. Les informations de la J=Haute Egypte sont très satisfaisantes; le Fayoum seul parle de retard.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: Cette semaine a bien débuté, mais de suite, un affaiblissement s'est produit, témoignant ainsi du manque de souffle du marche. Les essais de hausse ont pourtant été frequents, mais rien n'est venu répondre aux ardeurs des audacieux qui cherchaient a en profiter. La tension monteare persiste, parait-il, a Londres, car non seulement la place de New- Your est toujours mal pourvue, mais on s'y attend a une prolongation de cet état de choses. Une des plus grandes et des plus fortes com- pagnies americanizes de chemin de fer aurait decide de créer pour ses besoins urgents des bons 4 1/2 % a 18 mois de date et de les offrir a un prix légèrement inférieur au pair. Nous allons faire un relevé du marche de la semaine qui s'est beaucoup ressenti des nou- velles d'Europe et a été suddisament mouve- mente.
Samedi le marche très anime donne lieu a de grosses transactions, une hausse presque générale des valeurs se produit. L'opinion est bonne et tout le monde s'attend a ce que ce mouvement; continue.

Lundi, l'ouverture est bonne quelques affaires se font puis le marche s'affaiblit graduellement et cloture très calme. Mardi au contraire, nous a apporte un marche faible a l'ouverture, qui s'est termine assez ferme.
Mercredi marche faible, le cours s'alourdis- sent.
Jeudi, ouverture animée, quelques affaires ont été traitées spécialement dans le départe- ment des petites valeurs.
Aujourd'hui marche calme sans être mau- vais, la Delta Land presque seule a sonne lieu a quelques échanges; les autres valeurs res- tent stationnaires.

Le marche a eu, comme on le voit, de gran- des fluctuatuions; alternative de hauts et de bas qui nous fait penser qu'il serait utile de donner a nos lectures un relevé des divers cours des valeurs les plus échangées durant ces six derniers jours.

La Delta Land a eu les honneurs de la semaine, donnant lieu a de ombreuses affai- res, aussi, a-t-elle subi des carabins très sen- bibles. Samedi et lundi elle cote 4 7/32, mardi elle descend de 3/32 a 4 1/8; ce mouvement a la bailee s'accuentue mercredi ou elle cloture a 4. Jeudi nouvelle reprise de 3/32 a 4 3/32, aujourd'hui e'le faiblit de 1/32 a 4 1/16. L'agricole, est samedi et lundi a 9 7/8, elle perd 1/8 mardi a 9 3/4, depuis elle est restée stationnaire a ce dernier cours.

Les Estates, sont échangés samedi et lundi a 1 11/16, mardi ils baissent de 1/16 a 1 5/8, resent stationnaires mercredi, baissent encore de 1/32 a 1 19/32 jeudi, et aujourd'hui con- servent la meme cote qu'hier.

Les Urbaines a 6 1/4 samedi, s'addaiblissent de 1/16 a 6 3/16 lundi, cette baisse s'accentue mardi a 6 1/8; mercredi elles restent a 6 1/8, gagnent 1/16 a 6 3/16 jeudi, et reviennent aujourd'hui a 6 1/8.

Les Egyptian Hotels, spécialement, ont subi cette semaine un hausse sensible pleine- ment justifiée du reste, étant donne l'état florissant de cette société; nous donnons ci-dessous un petit appercu de sa situation presente.
Apres les ventes effectuées a ce jour, cette Compagnie possède encoure 65,000 mètres de terrain, y compris le domaine de Ghezireh Palace Hotel.
Ce domaine étant d'une superficie de 30,000 mètres, il resterait disponibles 35,000 mètres, pour lesquels des offres auraient été faites a raison de £ 10 le metro, ce qui représenterait £ 350,000.
On met aussi en ligne de compte la conces- sion d'eau et d'electricite pour l'ile de Ghezi- reh, que la Society ne se serait pas encore decided a cider pour £ 50,000.
Or, one value qu'avec le seul produit des ventes de terrains deja faites, les 115,000 ac- tions de la Societe pourraient être largement remboursées aux abords de £ 4.
En ajoutant le montant éventuel de la vente des 35,000 mètres restants, de la concession d'eau et d'electricite, etc., il s'ensuivrait que la valeur intrinsèque du titre serait d'enviren £ 10.

Pour ce qui des nouvelles concernant le project de creation d'une Society égyptienne en remplacement de a Compagnie actuelle, ces informations tendraient, dit-on, a se confirmer. Le capital de la Society nouvelle serait de L.E. 400,000 divise en 100.000 actions de L.E. 4, a la souscription desquelles le déten- teurs d'actions de l'ancienne Compagnie au- raient des droits de preference exceptionnelle- ment appréciables.

D'autre part, le Ghezireh Palace et le She- pheard's Hotel, dont il serait fait apport a la nouvelle Society, seraient estimes comme ayant actuellement une valeur approximative totale de 550.000 livres.

Les avis sont très patates sure le marche avenir, les uns prétendent qu'une reprise est inevitable, les autres au contraire soutiennent que les valeurs se maintiendront a leurs cours actuels, avec quelques petites fluctuations, jusqu'a la fin de la saison d'été.

Il est bien difficile dans ce cas de se faire un jugement, aussi croyons nous utile de recom- mander la prudence a nos lecteurs. Certes, notre de titres, qui ont subi ces der- tiers temps une depreciation assez sensible. sont bien au dessous de leur valeur réelleet sersient au prix actuel excellents a acheter, mais, quant a résoudre la question reprise ou non, cela nous parait impossible étant donne l'in0 decision qui règne pour le moment.

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

and a new existence imparted in place of what had so lately seemed worn-out, "used up," and valueless. This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.
THERAPION
